headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First off, I just wanted to follow up on some of the earlier answers and questions. Bill, you mentioned that there has been an improvement in sort of the share loss that you've seen this year versus last year. So could you just talk about what efforts you
componenttext: First off, I just wanted to follow up on some of the earlier answers and questions. Bill, you mentioned that there has been an improvement in sort of the share loss that you've seen this year versus last year. So could you just talk about what efforts you guys are putting underway that are sort of mitigating the share loss? And the sort of follow-up to that is I think you mentioned that there's a free EZ impact. If you could just clear that up for me, I think we had been under the assumption that the free EZ impact should have been lapped this year, and there shouldn't be any impact this year. So if you could just touch on those points, I'd appreciate it.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think part of the commentary on the free EZ is you have seen in the early season the shift to digital, that the Absolute Zero promotion has done, so I do think that there is a lot of free conversation that goes out there. So I think that has had an
componenttext: Yes, I think part of the commentary on the free EZ is you have seen in the early season the shift to digital, that the Absolute Zero promotion has done, so I do think that there is a lot of free conversation that goes out there. So I think that has had an impact. I'm not sure I remember the other part of the question.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was related to the programs we've done around share loss. So -- I mean, just to be clear, the sort of the ripple, the second year impact of free EZ, that happened as far as we can tell. But you saw a different creative from us this year. Some of t
componenttext: Yes, it was related to the programs we've done around share loss. So -- I mean, just to be clear, the sort of the ripple, the second year impact of free EZ, that happened as far as we can tell. But you saw a different creative from us this year. Some of the product that we made, detailed changes that we felt would be more appropriate for these target audiences, we've done some in-store distributions, or in-store merchandising is different. Some of the training has been different for the tax professionals themselves. There's been changes to some compensation programs. These are things that -- this is why we sort of get into this, many, many things that are going to be -- have to be looked at to solve this. Of course, we've been tapping a lot of those and there will be more to come.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And for my second question, just on ACA. Any early indications how the behavior of ACA-impacted filers is trending this season? Are you seeing any -- the higher penalties drive any shift in the behavior? Just overall, any differences that you'd ca
componenttext: Got it. And for my second question, just on ACA. Any early indications how the behavior of ACA-impacted filers is trending this season? Are you seeing any -- the higher penalties drive any shift in the behavior? Just overall, any differences that you'd call out in ACA behavior this year versus last?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think this season is showing some unusual filing patterns, so I don't think we have a good sense for it yet. We do believe that part of the delay to the season is due to the delays in these -- the 1095-Bs and Cs going out late. So we have seen few
componenttext: Well, I think this season is showing some unusual filing patterns, so I don't think we have a good sense for it yet. We do believe that part of the delay to the season is due to the delays in these -- the 1095-Bs and Cs going out late. So we have seen fewer clients than we expected -- but as Greg said, there's still 2 million filers to come, so we have to wait and see how the season plays out. So it's a little hard -- frankly, it's a little hard to read right now.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Everything we talked about in December with you, which is you all probably painfully remember, we did a lot of detail on ACA, still true and from our viewpoint. I actually, between -- it's just me speaking, I find it somewhat encouraging that there's a de
componenttext: Everything we talked about in December with you, which is you all probably painfully remember, we did a lot of detail on ACA, still true and from our viewpoint. I actually, between -- it's just me speaking, I find it somewhat encouraging that there's a delay in the season, because if part of it, which I think is reasonable, is ACA, that means people's behaviors are reflecting the realities of ACA. Now, how that plays out is still to be determined. And as we've said and will continue to say, this is a multiple year opportunity for us, but the best time to ask that question will really be at the end of the season, from our perspective.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And a quick follow-up on ACA, last one from me. It seems we've seen some ACA enrollment forecasts getting lowered this year. How are you guys feeling about that 20% to 25% ACA-impacted filer number longer term? Are you still sort of confiden
componenttext: Okay, got it. And a quick follow-up on ACA, last one from me. It seems we've seen some ACA enrollment forecasts getting lowered this year. How are you guys feeling about that 20% to 25% ACA-impacted filer number longer term? Are you still sort of confident in that? Or any changes to that figure longer term?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have not, at this point, updated that. Again, we want to see where things land. But at this point, we're holding to that. But we'll see how things play out. As we said, we're in a multiyear journey with this and we'll adjust if need be, depending
componenttext: Yes, we have not, at this point, updated that. Again, we want to see where things land. But at this point, we're holding to that. But we'll see how things play out. As we said, we're in a multiyear journey with this and we'll adjust if need be, depending upon where enrollments land and what the impact this season is. But at this point, we're holding to that belief.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger from Oppenheimer.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, guys. Obviously, you were pursuing early season volume this year via the ad campaign that we saw, with the $1 million-a-day giveaway. I'm curious, what type of impact do you feel that had? And does that come into any part of this EBITDA ma
componenttext: First question, guys. Obviously, you were pursuing early season volume this year via the ad campaign that we saw, with the $1 million-a-day giveaway. I'm curious, what type of impact do you feel that had? And does that come into any part of this EBITDA margin revision, where you're saying you'll still be above 28, but slightly below the 29 level this year? So it's a 2-part question, really how you feel about the ad campaign and if there's any impact on the margin. And then -- and Greg, if you could share on the margin, what the main components are, maybe in rank order.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take the first part. I think we felt very good about the program. I mean, it created a tremendous amount of in-store excitement. I was able to give a couple of checks out to winners, and it was very emotional, that we were able to -- I mean, par
componenttext: Yes, I'll take the first part. I think we felt very good about the program. I mean, it created a tremendous amount of in-store excitement. I was able to give a couple of checks out to winners, and it was very emotional, that we were able to -- I mean, part of it is, obviously $1,000, and part of it was just people feeling like I won something, and you heard that echo. We were even getting thank-you notes, which is very unusual for a tax preparation company. So we did have higher marketing expense in the third quarter in January, but as -- with regard to the EBITDA margin, I'll turn it over to Greg. We don't break out specifically what -- I mean, essentially, I think what we said is with the lower volume at this point, we wanted to alert you to we're probably on the lower end here, but I'll turn it over to Greg.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we've been very consistent. We've said to you all that 28% to 32% is the range for us in the short term and the medium term here. I think you also know, for those of you that's followed the story here for several years, we can change the margin wh
componenttext: Yes, so we've been very consistent. We've said to you all that 28% to 32% is the range for us in the short term and the medium term here. I think you also know, for those of you that's followed the story here for several years, we can change the margin when we want to. It wasn't that long ago, frankly, we were at 26% EBITDA margin, and we've been able to move it up. We've also been clear that our goal is not EBITDA margin as such, our goal is to get the revenue line moving. We've been making cost effort decisions constantly, but we are reinvesting that, in fact, somewhat disproportionally into the top line, and that's kind of what we've been doing. The slight revision to our margin is more just to kind of tighten it up in my viewpoint and the main driver there for us is just the volume pressure that we're seeing, because most of the other factors that we look at are actually pretty good. So we'll obviously be able to provide a more detailed reconciliation at the end of the tax season.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good segue to my second question. I was catching in the press release and in the commentary some glimpses of silver lining with regard to revenue per return. You all mentioned Peace of Mind, ID -- your ID product -- ID theft product. And this is
componenttext: That's a good segue to my second question. I was catching in the press release and in the commentary some glimpses of silver lining with regard to revenue per return. You all mentioned Peace of Mind, ID -- your ID product -- ID theft product. And this is a 2-parter again. I'm curious what you're seeing thus far as kind of a revenue per return offset versus the volume results we've seen? I know you're not going to give exact numbers. But anecdotally, if you could just share a little bit more. And the second part of the question, Greg, is you mentioned revenue deferral from one -- from beyond April, from one fiscal year to the other. Is that going to have a meaningful magnitude this year, do you believe, from what you've seen in the early season?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the first part of your question, Scott, your analytical silver lining insight is correct. We are seeing some positive movement across our entire business on revenue per user. At this point, we don't want to -- we've seen some positive on the attach
componenttext: So on the first part of your question, Scott, your analytical silver lining insight is correct. We are seeing some positive movement across our entire business on revenue per user. At this point, we don't want to -- we've seen some positive on the attach piece, as Greg indicated. But again, we've got to let the full season play out. We'll have full disclosure on all that, but we are seeing some positives on that.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so on the other question, which is the nuts and bolts of the way we account for things. And Scott, I know you know this, but for everyone else's benefit, if you go into our stores, you buy our products, which you should all buy our products, the Tax
componenttext: Yes, so on the other question, which is the nuts and bolts of the way we account for things. And Scott, I know you know this, but for everyone else's benefit, if you go into our stores, you buy our products, which you should all buy our products, the Tax Identity Shield is a great product, by the way. But last year, we bundled that product with the Peace of Mind product. This year, they're sold separately, as well as in a bundle. But you'll be able to see the Tax Identity Shield product is $30 for the year for the individual. The Peace of Mind is $35-ish. And we collect the cash from the client upfront, but the way it gets accounted is the Tax Identity Shield pretty much is 0 in the year it's sold. It's all recognized in the following year, for the most part. And then Peace of Mind is spread over really a 3-year period, with very little in the first year. So as those attach rates have been going up and as the units we've been selling had been going up, there's sort of an embedded accounting gain that will be realized in the next few years after that. So that's just accounting. As I said, we collect the cash.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Millman from Millman Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Millman from Millman Research.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sort of following up on some things. RALs were around last year, and so this year, maybe some of the amounts have increased, but it's not new, so not sure why it affected you maybe more this year. So I assume that the $1,000 promotion was your answer to R
componenttext: Sort of following up on some things. RALs were around last year, and so this year, maybe some of the amounts have increased, but it's not new, so not sure why it affected you maybe more this year. So I assume that the $1,000 promotion was your answer to RALs and why you talked about people excited. Not clear if it had much impact on your numbers. When we look at the numbers, we see that from the beginning of the year, these IRS numbers have shown nice increases each week from the beginning until this latest statistics, I guess, today's statistics. And we've also seen a good strength in do-it-yourself. Kind of curious, no one's asked, you started the year up about 5% and now you're down in do-it-yourself when TurboTax was going strong in January as well. So I'm not sure what the change is there. And then in terms of refunds, started off the year down 11%, but in the first week, I think the IRS released its money. And so basically, it's been kind of flat. Maybe refund's down 2% now. So a lot of, I guess, sort of out-of-mind type of commentary, but maybe you can give us some more flavor and more detail as to why some of these things seem to be different for you.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Greg, why don't you take that?
componenttext: So Greg, why don't you take that?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Mike, if I got it right, you've got 4 questions there, so we'll try to tackle each one for you. And then if we missed it, just let us know. But the first one, I think just factually, I disagree with your statement on RALs. So there were RAL
componenttext: Well, I think, Mike, if I got it right, you've got 4 questions there, so we'll try to tackle each one for you. And then if we missed it, just let us know. But the first one, I think just factually, I disagree with your statement on RALs. So there were RALs in the market last year. There were RALs the year before. These were sort of private, specific to state, quite small in nature. Last tax season, it was really only one provider that had RALs and they had an okay experience with that. We're very familiar with the details there. This season, you see both the other large branded competitors have them, as well as multiple providers that are also putting it through the independent channel, which is we all know is 40% of the revenue part of this market. So the number of distribution points for RALs this year is a lot larger than it was last year. And we're saying it's a factor. We're not saying it's a large factor. We're just saying it's a factor. So -- but just to make sure we get the facts straight on that one. And the next one I think was the $1,000, is that our response? Do you want on that one, Bill?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I wouldn't say it was a response. It was the approach we took for the early season clients, so I wouldn't say it was in response to the RAL.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I wouldn't say it was a response. It was the approach we took for the early season clients, so I wouldn't say it was in response to the RAL.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question was really about DIY trends, and we have Jason here. Do you want to talk about that, Jason?
componenttext: And the next question was really about DIY trends, and we have Jason here. Do you want to talk about that, Jason?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks for your question, Michael. I think our results really reflect our strategy for this season, which is we want to grow by attracting high-value clients at a rate that's faster than the category. And similar to last year, we started out slow co
componenttext: Sure. Thanks for your question, Michael. I think our results really reflect our strategy for this season, which is we want to grow by attracting high-value clients at a rate that's faster than the category. And similar to last year, we started out slow compared to the rest of the digital industry, but I'm really pleased with how we're serving these higher-value clients through our DIY products. We have NPS and our revenue per user that are both up tax season to-date. And from my perspective, there's a lot of season left, and the second half really holds the majority of these types of clients.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then lastly was really just about the refund volume and velocity. You're correct in terms of the direction of that. There is, and we mentioned this in the prepared remarks, directional differences within the types of people receiving refunds. It has b
componenttext: And then lastly was really just about the refund volume and velocity. You're correct in terms of the direction of that. There is, and we mentioned this in the prepared remarks, directional differences within the types of people receiving refunds. It has been a factor that we've been watching carefully this year. And really, from our point of view, we're just pointing it out more than anything else, just for education's perspective.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you elaborate on your launch of Block Advisors and how effective that's been in driving mix towards a higher-end and more complex demographic?
componenttext: Could you elaborate on your launch of Block Advisors and how effective that's been in driving mix towards a higher-end and more complex demographic?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we are now open, 286 locations around the country. We're very pleased with the opening. How the -- obviously, our first year, we want to make sure operationally you're getting all of that wired together. That's worked very well. Our tax pros, the
componenttext: Yes, so we are now open, 286 locations around the country. We're very pleased with the opening. How the -- obviously, our first year, we want to make sure operationally you're getting all of that wired together. That's worked very well. Our tax pros, the clients have come in, and effectively 2 things. One, this is now the season where Block Advisors really starts to kick into gear, the more complex client, the second half client. And clearly, there'll be a fairly large extensions group where -- as we look to see clients who are year-round. And so it's a long-term play for us. So we're not going to break out any specifics around it. It's just, suffice to say that I'm really pleased with the execution that has happened so far. But for the type of client that we're talking about, it's now starting to rev up for Block Advisors.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016

componenttextpreview: Sure. As I mentioned, George, we feel like we started out a little bit slow. I think that we have seen some shift move to the category leader, as they really worked with Absolute Zero and price on the desktop side in order to get that share. I think that
componenttext: Sure. As I mentioned, George, we feel like we started out a little bit slow. I think that we have seen some shift move to the category leader, as they really worked with Absolute Zero and price on the desktop side in order to get that share. I think that there's been more share that's gone to TaxACT and some of the smaller players, and that's really where we're headed at about halfway through the season.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And I guess, circling back to the assisted side, how would you assess the risk that some of the volume declines you're seeing this quarter are market share-driven rather than simply a timing element?
componenttext: Got it. And I guess, circling back to the assisted side, how would you assess the risk that some of the volume declines you're seeing this quarter are market share-driven rather than simply a timing element?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we've said this in the prepared remarks. But just to be clear, we've seen directionally continued improvement in our market share losses, so it's not a gain at this point. But from 3 years ago to 2 years ago, 2 years ago to last year and this
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we've said this in the prepared remarks. But just to be clear, we've seen directionally continued improvement in our market share losses, so it's not a gain at this point. But from 3 years ago to 2 years ago, 2 years ago to last year and this year, so the loss is getting better, so we're okay with that. I wouldn't say that we're pleased, because we're still losing.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Henry Chien calling for Jeff. I was wondering if you guys could talk a little bit more about the price and the mix improvements. Is there anything that you could share in terms of color of where you're getting these price increases and some more colo
componenttext: It's Henry Chien calling for Jeff. I was wondering if you guys could talk a little bit more about the price and the mix improvements. Is there anything that you could share in terms of color of where you're getting these price increases and some more color on where the mix improvements are?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so one of the nice things about our industry is we have real pricing power. I think you're all intimately familiar with that, but we measure elasticity in the assisted side, point 1. We have worked very hard the last several years to really -- to use
componenttext: Yes, so one of the nice things about our industry is we have real pricing power. I think you're all intimately familiar with that, but we measure elasticity in the assisted side, point 1. We have worked very hard the last several years to really -- to use pricing strategically, not opportunistically, not tactically. So we went to this tax season with a specific plan, a lot of nuance to it, but it's a way to really make sure that we hone our price value messaging to recognize the fact that we have this opportunity. And so we've executed that quite smoothly and generated some real value. Historically, as you know, we've basically been raising price at double the rate of inflation. We'll give you more guidance in what we did this year at the end of the season. And then in terms of the mix, this is a very big issue for us and we talk about units, units, units. This time of the year, that's the one thing we talk about. I always believe it's very misleading, because the units themselves, there's vast differences in the value of those, and so we recognize that in Block. We know the things that we do to help people and we've had a really, I think, good story where we continue to focus, of course, is the early season client. These are people where speed of refund matters and you get sort of 2 types of people typically in the early season, the EZ, the most basic filer, and then secondarily, is the Earned Income Credit filer. And we're more particularly focused on Earned Income Credit. We'll be able to better digest and share kind of results at the end of the season where that stands. But in total so far this year, we're pleased with mix. As we look to the second half, we continue to believe that's a good driver of value for us.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016

componenttext: No, I think it's been -- Henry, I think it's consistent with past year. I don't think there's been any particular demographic shift at this point.

componenttext: A couple more. The -- Greg, would love -- just the first one will be an update on Sand Canyon and what has occurred this quarter, and it sounds like a partial tolling agreement but maybe not complete. Just if you could elaborate to the extent you can.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in my mind, it's a good step forward for the Sand Canyon team. As we talked about earlier, there was, in my mind, a material reduction in the representation and warranty reserve by about $89 million. So we end up now with $65 million on the balance s
componenttext: Yes, in my mind, it's a good step forward for the Sand Canyon team. As we talked about earlier, there was, in my mind, a material reduction in the representation and warranty reserve by about $89 million. So we end up now with $65 million on the balance sheet for representation and warranty. The same kind of general work we've been using, it represents a small number of counter-parties, which the Sand Canyon management team are working through. What you saw this quarter was resolution on a few of those. I can't -- I'm not going to get too specific in the number, but we're talking, in total, still just a handful. So it does, at the same time, keep in mind, represent years of effort to get there, clearly because there's still a balance in that account, it means there's still some work to get done here, but it is a very positive step forward from our perspective.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple more. One is open ended, Tax Plus, if you could please elaborate on the good and the bad. And you already spoken a little bit to accounting changes there, but anything else you feel you should highlight? And then a quickie throw on is, Greg,
componenttext: Just a couple more. One is open ended, Tax Plus, if you could please elaborate on the good and the bad. And you already spoken a little bit to accounting changes there, but anything else you feel you should highlight? And then a quickie throw on is, Greg, I think the guide for the year, from the Investor Day for tax rate is 33% to 34%. It was a little off from that in this quarter from what we expected. Is that still a good number to use? And was that just a timing thing?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the first one. There's a lot of good on the attach. We're very excited about the increases we're seeing on the Tax Identity Shield, which is a product that is just spot on for what happens in the industry today. I think we're also pleased wit
componenttext: So I'll take the first one. There's a lot of good on the attach. We're very excited about the increases we're seeing on the Tax Identity Shield, which is a product that is just spot on for what happens in the industry today. I think we're also pleased with Peace of Mind continues to grow. We'll obviously give more color on this fully when the tax season is over. Emerald Card and Refund Transfer continue to be in line with history and consistent with the volume that we're seeing. But overall, we think the Tax Plus strategy is working quite well. Now, I'll turn it back to Greg.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so this is kind of the -- you have to sort of reverse your logic a little bit. In those quarters you lose money, you actually want your tax rate to be as high as possible. But the guidance we provided at December that you outlined would be what we wo
componenttext: Yes, so this is kind of the -- you have to sort of reverse your logic a little bit. In those quarters you lose money, you actually want your tax rate to be as high as possible. But the guidance we provided at December that you outlined would be what we would continue to reinforce, Scott. So as the year settles up, that would be the right range to think about for tax rate.

componenttext: Yes. The answer is yes at this point. I think we're trying to be cautious, Kartik, as we go through the end of the season. componenttext: Yes, not really, Kartik. We look at this -- I don't have a good answer for you other than I think our franchisees do a heck of a job, and I think they're doing marginally better than the company side, which is driving the company side crazy, because they're sort of competitive with each other. But there's nothing of note with that 70-basis-point difference.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, to me, this is an example why I'm always very cautious on units because as you know, a lot of our franchisees are more rural in nature. Our company are more city and suburbs. And when you actually neutralize for the sort of the mix within that, yo
componenttext: I mean, to me, this is an example why I'm always very cautious on units because as you know, a lot of our franchisees are more rural in nature. Our company are more city and suburbs. And when you actually neutralize for the sort of the mix within that, you find that the performance is actually pretty similar. In the big picture, in terms of things that really matter about running businesses, the company stores over time have shown their ability to show -- to sell the Tax Plus products at a much higher rate, thereby generating more value for the clients and also value for the company. And so that's -- when we said we think we manage the stores a little bit better, that's the main reason that we see differential over time.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016

componenttext: And then, Greg, just to make sure I understand, it's more of a housekeeping deal, but diluted share count you're expecting for the year, any difference? I know you bought back $392 million worth of shares. And for you guys, it's a little complicated to count the diluted shares. So I just want to make sure.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean the math on how to calculate the weighted average shares is a bit more complicated than it should be, but that's the way the GAAP works, and I think I know you know that. So we've given you where the share count was at the end of the third qua
componenttext: Yes, I mean the math on how to calculate the weighted average shares is a bit more complicated than it should be, but that's the way the GAAP works, and I think I know you know that. So we've given you where the share count was at the end of the third quarter. You could roll forward the math and using 1-, 2- and 3-quarter actuals, you'll have to take a position, because we're not going to give you an idea what the fourth quarter number is going to look like. But mathematically speaking, it's not going to be much different, just because of the way it works from a weighted perspective. So I don't know if that's helpful or not, but certainly, that's kind of my answer.

componenttext: Final thing I do want to say, and I encourage everyone on the phone, we'd love for you to be a client. headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Laurel, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the H&R Block Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the call over to Colby Brown, Vice President,
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Laurel, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the H&R Block Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the call over to Colby Brown, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laurel. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss our fourth quarter fiscal 2016 results. On the call today are Bill Cobb, our President and CEO; and Tony Bowen, our CFO. Greg Macfarlane, Senior Vice President, U.S. Reta
componenttext:
Thank you, Laurel. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss our fourth quarter fiscal 2016 results. On the call today are Bill Cobb, our President and CEO; and Tony Bowen, our CFO. Greg Macfarlane, Senior Vice President, U.S. Retail Products and Operations, will also be available during our question-and-answer session. In connection with this call, we have posted today's press release on the Investor Relations website at hrblock.com. Some of the figures that we'll discuss today are presented on a non-GAAP basis. We reconciled the comparable GAAP and non-GAAP figures in the schedules attached to our press release. 
Before we begin our prepared remarks, I'd like to remind everyone that this call will include forward-looking statements as defined in the securities laws. Such statements or based on current information and management's expectations as of this date and are not guarantees of future performance. Forward-looking statements involve certain risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. As a result, our actual outcomes and results could differ materially. You can learn more about these risks in our Form 10-K for fiscal 2015 and our other SEC filings. H&R Block undertakes no obligation to publicly update these risk factors or forward-looking statements. At the conclusion of our prepared remarks, we will have a Q&A session. [Operator Instructions] 
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Bill.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Colby, and good afternoon. Earlier today, we announced our results for fiscal year 2016. Clearly, this was a disappointing season on many fronts. Our assisted tax preparation business continues to lose returns, and for the first time in several
componenttext:
Thank you, Colby, and good afternoon. Earlier today, we announced our results for fiscal year 2016. Clearly, this was a disappointing season on many fronts. Our assisted tax preparation business continues to lose returns, and for the first time in several years, our digital do-it-yourself business did as well. Let me be clear. We will change the current loss trajectory and are hard at work to make this happen. Next season will not feel the same.
So with that as a backdrop, here's what we'll cover today. First, I'll spend a few minutes looking back at tax season '16. We did not deliver the results we wanted and for that, I take full responsibility. We have learned some hard lessons, and we'll change how we do business going forward. Next, I'll share our expectations for tax season '17 and beyond. We are fully committed to doing what it takes to turn our results around. Arresting the client decline and ultimately growing clients is our #1 objective. We cannot continue the client trajectory we've seen. Finally, I'll review the steps we are taking to achieve these objectives. Some have already been completed, many are in process, and others are yet  to start. I'm excited about the plans for fiscal year 2017 and beyond, and I'm confident we will execute on those plans to deliver better results. 
Let me, however, set some expectations upfront. I will not be able to provide full details regarding these plans, given how far out from the tax season we are and the competitive environment. But I can tell you that we are taking a broad look at our options and will be making meaningful changes in both the short and long term.
First, let's start by looking back at tax season 2016. From an industry perspective, the season started very slowly, and consistent with the past  few [ph] years, did not reach its expected growth level until the last week of the season. And the results seen this season were disappointing for most of the branded players, including H&R Block. One branded competitor, however, had an exceptional season. TurboTax absolute 0 promotion won the tax season and likely took share from all major branded competitors. Despite their success, however, the industry shift from assisted to DIY was relatively consistent with the last few years at approximately 90 basis points.
Although the assisted category grew slightly, we believe H&R Block and our assisted branded competitors lost share to independents. Based on our analysis, the independent shares in the market appears to have grown by approximately 80 basis points in tax season '16, continuing the trend we have seen for the past several years. 
Finally, this season, we saw increased fraud prevention measures at both the federal and state level. Stronger information security protocols in the DIY space were introduced to the public-private Security Summit, refund processing slowed at the federal level and states implemented measures designed to prevent and detect fraudulent activity. We will have a better idea of the impact these changes have on the industry when the IRS releases more information. In the meantime, our government relations team will continue to focus on finding fraud in all its forms, including tax identity theft and improper earned income tax payments, while my management team will be fully focused on running the business.
Fraud is not the only issue we face and as such, a solution to fraud is not the only answer to client growth.
Now let me discuss what happened in the industry, and let's talk about H&R Block's results. We will have [ph] 6% of our clients in the assisted channel or 1 point of share. The majority of the client loss, again, came from the early-season filers obtaining the Earned Income Tax Credit and those filings have the 1040EZ Form. Those losses have [indiscernible] while our retention levels have held steady over the last several years. What this means is that we are not driving new clients into our offices at an acceptable rate. So why are we declining in clients? Well, there isn't a single simple answer for this question. There are few things we can point to. This includes aggressive and compelling similar promotions and product and service offerings for both independents and DIY competitors, including the recently reintroduced Refund Anticipation Loan or RAL-like product in the assisted channel. While we cannot just look externally in our assessment, the truth is we do not perform well as a company. We saw a poor execution in all areas of our business: sales, marketing and field operations. I intend for this to be the last time you'll hear me say this. We do not intend to be outplayed again.
In order to move forward, we need to understand what didn't work, which I've just described, but we also need to capitalize on what has worked. In the past, we talked to you about the 4 components of revenue: price, mix, volume and product attached. Although volume was down, the other 3 components positively impacted results. We achieved the 3% average price increase we have planned. Overall, form mix continued to improve, contributing an additional 1% in revenue growth. Overall product attached also increased, driven by our Peace of Mind and Tax Identity Shield products. And despite the fact that we declined the most in early season clients, which impacts Emerald Card and refund transfer unit sales, attach rates for these 2 products in our retail offices were strong at 15% and 33%, respectively. We also had a strong first season with our new bank partner. The transition of our products was efficient, resulting in a seamless experience for tax professionals and clients. 
Finally, in the assisted space, we were pleased with the launch of our new brand and look forward to growing that business to over 350 locations in fiscal 2017. As we mentioned before the season, this is a long-term investment for us, although I'm pleased with the progress today.
In our DIY business, returns declined 2.6% [ph], resulting in a 1 point loss of share. Yes, Turbo had a great season, but we also know that we do not market our product appropriately, demonstrated by the fact that our DIY awareness continues to linger in the mid-60s range. This actually represents a great opportunity for us. We have seen in the past that with the right marketing, we can drive client revenue growth. Our average revenue per client in DIY increased due to pricing enhancements to the product, improved monetization and an increase in product attached. Conversion rates also increased 1 point, and our mobile usage increased significantly.
Moving to the Affordable Care Act, we do not see the impact we expected as early season client losses disproportionately affected ACA-related volume. In addition, IRS compliance efforts around ACA penalties were not yet visible to taxpayers, which we believe led to continued and potentially increased tax noncompliance. As such, the percent of ACA-impacted clients decreased slightly from 16% to 15%. In the ACA-impacted client base, we did see an increase in the number of clients completing the premium tax credit reconciliation at -- as expected which is the most complex of the 3 ACA forms [indiscernible] The ACA impacts an important segment of our client base, and we believe will result in growth over time. However, that growth is dependent on 3 things: First, our ability to grow clients who are impacted by the ACA, particularly early season filers; second, overall growth and marketplace enrollment; and third, increased IRS compliance enforcement, which we believe will start to happen later this calendar year.
Now with that overview of the business, let me provide a couple of additional thoughts on our financial performance. Coming into the year with the divestiture of H&R Block Bank, we had anticipated a 1% drop in revenue and a 1 point decline in adjusted EBITDA margin. Actual results were in line with expectations, resulting in a $35 million reduction in EBITDA. We also incurred additional headwinds due to foreign exchange rate fluctuations that negatively impacted revenues by another point. Excluding the 2 points decrease due to these impacts, overall revenues for the year increased compared to the prior year.
Turning to the balance sheet, we made great progress in aligning our capital structure with our business model this year. We divested our bank to provide capital flexibility and have been able to retain a significant -- return a significant amount of capital to shareholders. In FY '16, we repurchased 56.4 million shares, representing over 20% [ph] of outstanding shares since the beginning of the fiscal year. I am also pleased with the announcement today that the Board of Directors has approved a 10% increase in our quarterly dividend. Tony will speak to our dividend approach later in the call.
With fiscal 2016 behind us, it's now time to look to the future. Going forward, our #1 goal is to arrest the client decline and ultimately achieve client growth. To do this, we must improve the value we provide to our clients and do a better job of communicating this value. We will fix this, both in the short term and the long term. In the short term, we will make significant aggressive changes aimed at driving client volumes. As we approach next season, we are reviewing our marketing efforts, product offerings, promotions and service delivery models. Understand, however, that we will not sacrifice the long term good of our company for a short-term gain. In the long term, we must consider the tax preparation needs of the market overall. We are the only company that can serve clients would be want to be served and have the opportunity to expand our offerings to appeal to the very market today. You will see innovative solutions designed to leverage our ability to serve clients anyway they want to be served. To deliver on these goals, we are investing in research and development. These investments will be funded through our cost reduction efforts, which I'll talk about in a moment.
So now that we know what we need to do, how will we do it? There are 3 main pieces to our fiscal year 2017 strategy. First, we will implement programs specifically designed to drive new client growth, and I'm excited about what we'll bring to the market next season. Next, we have evaluated all aspects of the business and identified cost savings throughout. This includes realigning our field management and identifying efficiencies at our corporate headquarters, allowing us to reduce headcount and sharpen our focus on delivering client growth. Additionally, we'll spend less on marketing and have taken out IT infrastructure and support costs. Collectively, these actions will enable us to ensure strong free cash flow going forward while funding our client acquisition initiatives and R&D efforts mentioned earlier. Given how far we are from the next tax season and the competitive environment, it is too early to share specifics regarding both our fiscal 2017 initiatives and our margin expectation. That said, we are not moving away from our long-term EBITDA margin guidance of 28% to 32%. We will provide more details on the operational changes and financial expectations at our investor conference in December.
Finally, I have reorganized my management leadership team. I have flattened the organization, divided it into more discrete areas of responsibility, taken on more direct reports, increased individual leader accountability and ultimately, assumed a more operational role. Overall, I am very pleased with what this team has achieved in the first 50 days since the changes were implemented. They are focused on the right objectives and are working diligently to achieve them. Caroline Roscoe, a nearly 17-year veteran of H&R Block will lead the sales side of the company on assisted business, and Keith Knight to lead a franchise side. Heather Watts, an experienced DIY professional will lead our DIY business. In line with our research and development efforts, I'm pleased to announce that Jason Houseworth is now our Chief Innovation Officer, tasked with bringing solutions to taxpayers in new and creative ways. In this role, Jason will lead a cross-functional organization and is focused on innovation in the tax industry, specifically around the clients' tax filing experience. And I have moved Greg Macfarlane into a role where he will be responsible for all products and operations that support our retail business. Greg's operational mindset and business acumen will enable us to leverage his talents in an even more meaningful way going forward.
Which leads me to Tony Bowen who is taking on the role of CFO. Tony has all the variety of financial roles throughout his 12-plus years at H&R Block. Most recently, he led the U.S. tax finance organization, working very closely with Greg and me. his institutional knowledge makes them a great addition to my leadership team, and a strong financial acumen makes him an excellent choice as CFO. I'm excited about the Tony brings to our organization, and I'm confident that you will appreciate working with him in the months and years ahead.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Tony.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and good afternoon. First, I would like to think Bill and the Board of Directors for this opportunity. I would also like to thank Greg for his guidance and support. He's been a great mentor during my time in his team and has big shoes to fil
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and good afternoon. First, I would like to think Bill and the Board of Directors for this opportunity. I would also like to thank Greg for his guidance and support. He's been a great mentor during my time in his team and has big shoes to fill. I'm excited about being the CFO of H&R Block despite having a difficult season I know from my 12 years here at this great company with great people. And what we do for our clients is important, helping them with what for many is our largest financial transaction of the year. This is a great business with a solid financial model that generates strong free cash flow and provides an excellent return on capital. I believe in the future of this company and look forward to serving as CFO.
So today, I'd like to talk about fiscal 2016 results, the financial strength of the company and my thoughts around capital structure. 
First, let's talk about our results. In essence, this was a reset year regarding our financials, given the divestiture of the bank and the subsequent capital structure changes. Revenue decreased 1.3% to just over $3 billion, primarily due to lower tax return volumes. As we stated at our investor conference, we expected the bank divestiture to have a 1 point annual impact on revenues and a 1 point impact on EBITDA margins. The actual impact was consistent with this guidance. In addition to the impact related to the bank divestiture, total revenues were negatively impacted 1% due to foreign exchange rate fluctuations in our Canadian and Australian operations. Excluding the impact of the bank divestiture and foreign exchange, revenues would've increased by approximately 0.5% over the prior year. 
Turning to assisted, return volume decline of 6% were partially offset by price increases of about 3%. In addition, we had a 1% increase due to improved mix as most of our volume losses were in less complex returns in the early part of the tax season. Lower tax return volume also resulted in lower overall product revenue. Despite the volume loss, however, we were able to increase product attached per client. This was driven by increases in attach rates from our Peace of Mind and Tax Identity Shield products. We also issued 1.8 million Emerald Card in tax season in 2016, and revenue per card increased 2% from the prior year to $52 per card. DIY tax preparation revenues increased 1.1% to $234 million, despite a reduction in return volume. Improved pricing and monetization efforts do an enhanced product flow contributed to the revenue increase. Additionally, we improved our refund transfer product attaching our DIY online offering. Internationally, local currency revenues increased slightly compared to the prior year, while U.S. dollars revenues were negatively impacted $26 million by foreign currency translation adjustments.
Turning to expenses, operating expenses increased 5.3% from the prior year, mainly due to expenses resulted from independent and franchise acquisitions and increased marketing expenses related to the early season sweepstake promotion. This is partially offset by the decline in compensation and benefit expenses, driven by the decrease in tax return volume. We completed the year with an adjusted EBITDA margin of 28%, which is in line with a guidance provided in the mid-season volume update, with the issuance of an additional $1 billion of long-term debt in September 2015 and the increased borrowings under our lines of credit. Total interest expense for FY '16 was $69 million. This represented an increase of $24 million from the prior year. We were pleased that our effective tax rate decreased approximately 2 points to 32.6%, mainly due to favorable discrete items. Notwithstanding that, we expect our long-term base rate to be in the 35% to 36% range. Finally, the company's overall free cash flow for the year declined 14% to $432 million, and adjusted earnings per share was $1.59. 
Turning to discontinued operations, Sand Canyon's accrual for contingent losses related to representation of foreign claims was $65 million as of April 30. As a reminder, Sand Canyon is and always has been operated as a separate legal entity from H&R Block. We continue to believe our legal position is strong on any potential deal piercing arguments. Next I'd like to discuss capital allocation. After divesting the bank last September we returned, to our historical practice repurchasing of shares and increasing our dividend. We repurchased 3.9 million shares during the fourth quarter, bringing our fiscal year total repurchases to 56.4 million shares or more than 20% of outstanding shares. We remain committed to returning capital to share repurchases, and that we are going to discuss specific plans for this year. We would get more guidance later in the call.
During the leverage, we previously shared that we intend to maintain investment grade metrics. We believe that to do this we need to maintain an adjusted gross debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio of 2.5 to 3x. Based on this year's fiscal results, we are now in that range. As such, we don't plan to issue any incremental debt in the near term to finance share repurchases. We will continue to evaluate the appropriate debt level as part of our overall capital structure plans going forward. Regarding dividends, the Board of Directors approved a 10% increase in the quarterly dividend. This increase represents a bit of a catch-up, given our inability to increase the dividend during the past few years while we were regulated as a savings loan holding company. Going forward, we are committed to an annual review of our dividend after each fiscal year. Any decisions regarding future dividends will depend in our operating results, market conditions and capital needs among other factors.
Turning to fiscal 2017, while we are focused on arresting the client decline, we've also completed a comprehensive review of our cost structure and implemented many of the cost reduction efforts Bill mentioned earlier. Because we are still in the planning process, we will provide more specifics for fiscal year 2017 at our investor conference in December.
With that, I will now turn the call over to Bill for some final comments.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony. We've covered quite a bit of information today. I want to emphasize that although we had a disappointing tax season, H&R Block continues to be a strong company with an experienced focus management team that will deliver better results goi
componenttext: Thank you, Tony. We've covered quite a bit of information today. I want to emphasize that although we had a disappointing tax season, H&R Block continues to be a strong company with an experienced focus management team that will deliver better results going forward. We are taking full responsibility and are addressing the issues of last season. You heard me say before but repeating here. I own what happened. And that end, I will not receive a performance bonus of this year. Looking forward, my senior leaders and I are very competitive group. We do not like to lose. We are smarter than we were at the beginning of this season and the lessons learned for tax season '16 will benefit us in the long-range. We are aggressively focused on arresting the client decline going forward, and we will deliver results on tax season '17. I look forward to sharing more of our specific plans as we get closer to the start of the tax season. We are now ready to open the call for questions. Operator?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- not much color on what's going to happen next year at this juncture. With the -- though you'd said at the beginning, growing clients is the #1 objective and clearly in season. You also said that marketing will be an area of expense reduction, and y
componenttext: The -- not much color on what's going to happen next year at this juncture. With the -- though you'd said at the beginning, growing clients is the #1 objective and clearly in season. You also said that marketing will be an area of expense reduction, and you specified initially. I'm curious what is the spend thought on marketing next year? And I would imagine you're probably going to have to consider some pricing reductions perhaps around 1040EZ or a loan product being offered new. So a lot in the there, but if you could just address all of the above.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, you always have a lot in there. So let me address a couple of the comments you made. One is, overall, yes, you're right. I'm not going to get into specifics. Everything is on the table. I wanted to be very clear with all of you what our objective i
componenttext: Scott, you always have a lot in there. So let me address a couple of the comments you made. One is, overall, yes, you're right. I'm not going to get into specifics. Everything is on the table. I wanted to be very clear with all of you what our objective is, and we're studying that right now and are putting plans together. I do think we can be more efficient in marketing, that's going to be more impactful, and so that's why we'll spend less next year, but I'm not going to quantify the exact number. So that's kind of the overview program, but let me address pricing because I do think that if you think about where the pricing piece goes, this gets to be kind of a complicated issue. I think that it's very strategic in the response we have to take, but let me try to lay out there I think we are. One is I think we're in line with our competitors. I think with some independents, we're higher priced. With our branded competitors in the assisted channel, we are beneath them. But I do think that we do have pockets of clients where it's clear we're going to have taken difficult approach to our pricing. I think that there are some value initiatives that we're going to have to look closely at on a surgical or strategic basis. I think having settled that, I do believe we still have the ability to take price increases, but I do think that they are going to be modest as we go forward.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bill, just following up. Any consideration, not sure what you'll provide, but next year there is the EITC clients, there is a mandate that refunds will be delayed until February 15th, and that will likely cost probably a bit of a change in behavior an
componenttext: And Bill, just following up. Any consideration, not sure what you'll provide, but next year there is the EITC clients, there is a mandate that refunds will be delayed until February 15th, and that will likely cost probably a bit of a change in behavior and also potentially an opportunity. You did address some of the products out there in the early season. Just what are your high-level thoughts on that dynamic. And not that you're going to share too much about consideration for such a product, but anything that you're thinking on that level.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, no specifics, but I do think you're onto what I think is going to be a big change in the market next year. I think this is going to be well known in the market. I think this will be in the mainstream press that refunds are delayed due to the p
componenttext: Yes. Again, no specifics, but I do think you're onto what I think is going to be a big change in the market next year. I think this is going to be well known in the market. I think this will be in the mainstream press that refunds are delayed due to the past February 15. I do think that is going to have an impact on the market, and we plan to take advantage of that.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Thomas Allen with Morgan Stanley.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when you talk about your initiatives to improve, you noted that, that will be funded through the cost reduction plan. Should we take this as the cost reduction plan will be x dollars, and all that will be put into kind of incremental ways to drive an i
componenttext: So when you talk about your initiatives to improve, you noted that, that will be funded through the cost reduction plan. Should we take this as the cost reduction plan will be x dollars, and all that will be put into kind of incremental ways to drive an improvement in top line?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what I was trying to convey -- and again, we're not going to quantify this when we get to investor conference, we're using much more specific in our plans, the puts and takes, but I do want to make it clear that we did take an aggressive post
componenttext: Yes. I think what I was trying to convey -- and again, we're not going to quantify this when we get to investor conference, we're using much more specific in our plans, the puts and takes, but I do want to make it clear that we did take an aggressive posture on cost reductions because we knew as the season started in to unfold that this is not turning out the way we wanted it to. So I moved quickly in March and April to be aggressive on cost reductions. But I also wanted to convey to everybody that we are not -- as you go aggressively, client growth or arresting the client decline, that's going to cost us some thing. So I wanted to be able to balance the savings that we get from cost reductions with what we believe will help to offset the costs of trying to drive our client growth up again. So...

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up question -- I understand your reasoning for more detail on the plan, given competitive rationale and -- but in reality, your assisted volumes have been down 3% to 6% for each year for the past 4 years. So I'd just -- for the benefit
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up question -- I understand your reasoning for more detail on the plan, given competitive rationale and -- but in reality, your assisted volumes have been down 3% to 6% for each year for the past 4 years. So I'd just -- for the benefit of investors, any more anecdotes on how you think you can turn them around to, given the fact that this has been a 4-year decline, not just a 1-year decline.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you even noted this in one of your recent reports. We are very focused on profitable growth that obviously needs to continue to be part of our arsenal, but the decline in the early season has been tough for us, so I think we have to adjust th
componenttext: Yes, I think you even noted this in one of your recent reports. We are very focused on profitable growth that obviously needs to continue to be part of our arsenal, but the decline in the early season has been tough for us, so I think we have to adjust that most specifically to decline in the 1040EZ client and the EITC client, so that is where a lot of our efforts will be spent.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: So with regard to the first question, we believe our estimates are -- it's a hazy, but we think 1 million RALs were done between the independence and JH and Liberty. So we think the number was in the range of about 1 million RALs, so I think it did have an impact on us, and I think we have to bring that into consideration. With regard to absolute 0, this -- if you go back to this time last year, we're reporting results in line with Turbo in terms of number of returns, and our revenue on a percentage basis was actually higher. We chose to stay with the same strategy for this upcoming year and it didn't work. They outplayed us, as I said. So again, I'm not going to comment specifically, but we are quite mindful that absolute 0 is here to stay, and we'll have to figure out and actually, we're in the process of doing that right now.

componenttext: But I do think with regard to buybacks, Gil, I think we had indicated in our conversations previously that we would be tempering that going forward. headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Here's what I would say. We cannot -- the volume decline we saw on both sides of our business last tax season we, cannot sustain that. We do not want to be in that direction. So we have got to be aggressive on recapturing clients, and we're arresting the
componenttext: Here's what I would say. We cannot -- the volume decline we saw on both sides of our business last tax season we, cannot sustain that. We do not want to be in that direction. So we have got to be aggressive on recapturing clients, and we're arresting the client decline. We do believe the early season client has been a particular problem for us, and we are committed to try to reverse our trends in that area, specifically, but overall, so again, not going to say specifically what we're going to do, but I think what I'm trying to do is provide what our objectives are, what our priority is, where our focus is, and then we'll talk to specifics as we get to the tax season.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, on the commentary that you made on the execution issues, you referenced that you guys have aggressively moved to resolve them or have resolved some of them. Can you give some more specific examples of the execution things that went wrong? And when d
componenttext: Bill, on the commentary that you made on the execution issues, you referenced that you guys have aggressively moved to resolve them or have resolved some of them. Can you give some more specific examples of the execution things that went wrong? And when do you think you guys can get to market-like growth in assisted? Is '17 the year that we perhaps see you guys maintain share and grow in line with the market? And perhaps this is further out, but do you guys think that these initiatives are setting the stage or perhaps even above market growth?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, Anj, I'll get to your execution point, but let me address the -- I'm not going to, at this point, give any specific numbers on what we think will do in terms of client growth. We have to stop the bleeding. We have to turn north. We have to, and ult
componenttext: Again, Anj, I'll get to your execution point, but let me address the -- I'm not going to, at this point, give any specific numbers on what we think will do in terms of client growth. We have to stop the bleeding. We have to turn north. We have to, and ultimately, as I said in the script, have to go grow clients. So that -- and whether that's in '17, we're still modeling everything out, but the direction of our team very aggressive. On the execution front and, as I said, I own this, I drove all of these initiatives. We missed on the sweepstakes it underperformed. I don't think this is our best year in marketing. I think that from a sales perspective, I think our field team -- everybody worked hard, everybody did their best, but we did not capture new clients at the rate that we have in the past. So I don't think our efforts at the local level were very strong. I think there were some execution hiccups also. And on the DIY side, I think we're very pleased with our product performance, and our reviews continue to show what the strong product we have that matches up very well with TurboTax. We just did the combination of marketing and really attracting new clients work. So I was talking to somebody recently and I said, normally in business, a few things hit, few things mess and you hope you move ahead and every once in a while you had done everything. This was a perfect storm the runway. Virtually everything whether it be foreign currency, the recent year would everything went the wrong way here. That's why I think, ultimately, this was a bad bad tax season. That's the way I'm approaching it. We are going to turn this around. We're going to fix this but it was one bad season. It's the way I really look at it. I think another seasons we've had some plus and minus stuff we've been able to move forward with incredible results this year, they were unacceptable, and we're committed to turn that around.

componenttext: Okay. Got it. And I'm also trying to understand why were they not previously done? Were they deemed too insignificant to be done and now you've found more opportunity? Or is it something else?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Frankly, I'm not going to look back. I mean I can kick myself all day for I should've done this and I should should've done that, and we didn't. We missed. We are going forward aggressively. My plan is to have everything in place as they said we are
componenttext: Yes. Frankly, I'm not going to look back. I mean I can kick myself all day for I should've done this and I should should've done that, and we didn't. We missed. We are going forward aggressively. My plan is to have everything in place as they said we are some tests going to put in place because we want to make sure we are set up for fiscal '18. I'm not putting all the -- because I think that we have to look at this on a multiyear basis in a highly seasonal business like this, and you heard me talk about that. the most seasonal business in the S&P 500, when you miss, it hurts, and it hurts a lot. So we will not only be looking to -- I think that anything we want to do in '17 on a national basis, we will be able to do that. I don't see any impediments to that. And in addition to that, we're going to be testing some things that they think we'll have some great impact in '18.

componenttext: So I do think, as I said earlier, I think the early season client is one we are addressing, will be addressing aggressively. I also stated earlier when I was talking to Scott that we do believe and we've got to be strategic that he will have an ability to be -- to still have pricing as a positive aspect of our revenue, but I think it's going to be more modest as we go forward and much more surgical in terms of the way we apply that.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So following up about and some other things, talking about the independents, obviously, their share in assisted was up. To what extent do you think it's pricing that's doing this much more than -- or red tape much more than, say, RALs, for example? And al
componenttext: So following up about and some other things, talking about the independents, obviously, their share in assisted was up. To what extent do you think it's pricing that's doing this much more than -- or red tape much more than, say, RALs, for example? And also, you talked about how clients are weak actually for the last several years. Could you talk about, on the other side of the coin, client retention, particularly retention in different categories EX and 40A and the total 40? And then finally ACA, should we lower our sights for significantly the impact that ACA is going to have on you and the industry?

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me try to take that one at that time. On independents, I think a couple of things there. You mentioned pricing. I think that has an impact. I think -- as I said earlier, I think we need some more information on exactly what has happened there, i
componenttext: Okay. Let me try to take that one at that time. On independents, I think a couple of things there. You mentioned pricing. I think that has an impact. I think -- as I said earlier, I think we need some more information on exactly what has happened there, it's tough in the independent space. I think a lack of minimal standards, which I continue to talk about as one of our top 2 government relations initiatives continues to hurt us, because part of independents is fraudulent providers. But again, I don't want to spend a lot of time on fraud. Our -- we continue to work on our government relations initiatives, but we have to focus on executing better. So we need more analysis on the independent space. But obviously, we don't like to see them growing while we're not. With regard to retention, our retention continues to be very strong. There is no change our issue this year was the lack of attraction of new clients so we were not able to get the new clients we've seen in the past, but our retention continues to be quite strong. And then finally from an ACA perspective, I do think, frankly, we were surprised by this year's results. The number of enrollees have gone up almost 50% to 11.7 million. And frankly, we had very little change in the amount of clients that are impacted. Last year, we had 16% client impacted. This year, was 15%. We did have more clients who were completing their premium tax credit, but to say that this was expected is not true. We were surprised ourselves. I do want to say though a few things. One, the exchanges continue to grow. There's another million people enrolled in the exchanges this year. It's almost 13 million people enrolled in '16. I think the -- I think there has been some noncompliance checking the boxes because IRS auditing efforts haven't begun they're going to begin this summer. IRS is going to be able to match the 1095s the people who did not file correctly. So I think you will see more stepped-up awareness that the IRS is coming after this. I also think that with our focus on early season volumes, I think that is going to help us also. I think with our miss in the early season it's hurt us on the piece. So I believe that the long-term this is still a deal in for us I think this is going to continue to grow. I think it's still going to be a positive for us. Frankly, I think we had a bump this year that we're a little surprised I think in the long run that this is still a benefit to H&R Block.

headline: H&R Block, Inc., 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just step back on this because I think it's an important aspect, and I think many of you have been asking for us to comment on our dividend policy. For years, we have not been able to issue dividends or issue any change in dividends because of our
componenttext: Let me just step back on this because I think it's an important aspect, and I think many of you have been asking for us to comment on our dividend policy. For years, we have not been able to issue dividends or issue any change in dividends because of our being tied up with the bank and Dodd-Frank, so we have not commented on our -- in any kind of dividend policy or the like. When we left the bank in September and came out of our capital plan, we said we would talk about dividends at the time when we think it's appropriate, which is every June. And what we committed to is we will have an annual review of the dividend in June because that's the time of the year we're 3 quarters of our revenue or more in the fourth quarter, that's the appropriate time for us to be discussing any change in the dividend. So we are committing to investors that we will have that annual review. Specific to this year, we felt that early on in my tenure, we did increase the dividend 33%. We haven't done it for almost 4 years, so we thought it appropriate for us to do a 10% increase at this moment. That will be effective with the dividend payable July 1, so that's what we announced today was a 10% increase, and then we'll in have an annual review of the dividend every June.

componenttext: Yes. We have not just come up with -- let me put it this way. We committed to an annual review. We're not going to give into payout ratio or anything else. We'll take an assessment of how the tax season  and what our situation is what our market conditions and then be transparent in terms of what our position is going forward.
